qas.question: What type of mosaic uses small tesserae?
What was the benefit of using small pieces to create a mosaic?
What were small panel mosaics known as?
What was the name of the mosaic technique that used larger tesserae?
Why were black and white pieces used in most italian mosaics?

context: There were two main techniques in Greco-Roman mosaic: <a0_0>opus vermiculatum<a0_0/> used tiny tesserae, typically cubes of 4 millimeters or less, and was produced in workshops in relatively small panels which were transported to the site glued to some temporary support. The tiny tesserae allowed <a1_0>very fine detail<a1_0/>, and an approach to the illusionism of painting. Often small panels called <a2_0>emblemata<a2_0/> were inserted into walls or as the highlights of larger floor-mosaics in coarser work. The normal technique was <a3_0>opus tessellatum<a3_0/>, using larger tesserae, which was laid on site. There was a distinct native Italian style using black on a white background, which was no doubt <a4_0>cheaper than fully coloured work<a4_0/>.
